tasks.task: Siting and building a quality pond.
subtasks: Consider the amount of soil to be moved.
Determine the volume of water to be held.
Ensure at least 8 feet depth (15 feet if possible) to prevent winter kills.
Use clay-rich soil for the dam as it compacts well and holds water.
Check natural pinch points in the watershed to minimize soil movement.
Examine the watershed's soil and nutrient content for suitability.
Ensure the dam has a 3:1 slope (1 foot rise per 3 feet run) for aquatic plants and fish habitat.
Clear trees near the pond edge for fish habitat and to reduce shading.

tasks.task: Contacting the fisheries and aquaculture extension specialist.
subtasks: Reach out to Alan Patilla for further inquiries related to pond construction.
** Assess the amount of soil needed for the pond. (Ponds require significant soil movement; it's the primary expense.)
** Determine the optimal water volume. (Volume affects dam design and fish survival.)
** Choose the right soil type. (Clay compacts well and retains water better than sand.)
** Ensure depth for winter survival (8 feet is minimum; 15 feet preferred). (Prevent winter kills.)
** Select appropriate dam slope. (3:1 slope prevents aquatic plant growth beyond 10 feet.)
** Check watershed for natural pinch points. (These minimize soil movement and maximize water retention.)
** Remove trees next to the dam for fish habitat. (Promotes congregation of fish.)
** Clear trees to reduce shading (which can affect aquatic plant growth).
** Contact Alan Patilla for further advice (his name and contact info are provided).
